abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Employment Generation Project in Haiti.
            The objectives of the project were to: (a) create short-term
            employment for people in extreme poverty in support of the
            Borrower's program for poverty alleviation; (b)
            rehabilitate seriously deteriorated economic and productive
            infrastructure in the Borrower's country; and (c)
            strengthen the capacity of non-government and community
            organizations operating in the territory of the Borrower to
            manage labor intensive small-scale development projects,
            including the establishment of a national non-government
            contract management entity; (d) development of a longer term
            strategy for poverty alleviation, employment and small
            infrastructure maintenance. Bank performance is rated highly
            satisfactory. The Borrower's performance is rated
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned were: (i) a
            partnership between public and private and non-governmental
            sectors can live up to tremendous challenges; (ii) not all
            infrastructure rehabilitation sub-projects are suited for
            labor-intensive methods; (iii) extensive participation with
            beneficiaries and local authorities are necessary from the
            inception of sub-projects to ensure sustainable maintenance
            and operation; (iv) the Bank and the government are able to
            move very fast when supported by senior officials; and (v)
            more realism is needed about what can be achieved in terms
            of institutional development in a short time period and in
            an environment such as the one prevailing in Haiti in 1995-1996.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Employment Generation Project will
            provide short term employment to people in extreme poverty
            in support of the Government's programs for poverty
            alleviation. By doing so, the project will continue to
            support for job creation efforts undertaken since 1993, and
            achieve other objectives including the improvement of
            seriously deteriorated economic and productive
            infrastructure. In addition, the project will strengthen the
            capacity of national and local government, nongovernmental
            organizations and local community organizations to manage
            employment-intensive small scale development projects in the
            future. The project will have an employment generation
            component as well as an institutional development component.
